questions.question: A Product Owner wants to establish a consistent rhythm for stakeholder feedback. What Sprint duration approach would best support this goal?
options: Vary Sprint lengths based on the complexity of work
Use exactly 2 weeks for all Sprints
Choose a consistent duration of one month or less and maintain it
Extend Sprints when more feedback is needed
questions.explanation: Sprints should have a consistent duration of one month or less to create a predictable rhythm for stakeholder feedback and team planning. Consistency enables better forecasting and stakeholder engagement.

questions.question: A Product Owner asks how they can track the Development Team's progress during the Sprint. What should they be told?
options: Monitor individual developer productivity metrics
Attend Daily Scrums to track task completion
The Development Team manages their own progress toward the Sprint Goal
Review detailed time tracking reports
questions.explanation: The Development Team is responsible for managing their own progress during the Sprint. The Product Owner should focus on Sprint Goal achievement rather than micromanaging daily activities.

questions.question: A Product Owner discovers that incomplete work from the current Sprint includes a partially implemented feature that stakeholders really want. What should they do with this work?
options: Automatically add it to the next Sprint since it's partially done
Return it to the Product Backlog and reprioritize it based on current value
Extend the current Sprint to complete the feature
Ask the Development Team to finish it outside of Sprint time
questions.explanation: Incomplete work should be returned to the Product Backlog and reprioritized based on current value. The Product Owner shouldn't assume previous priority still applies and should make fresh prioritization decisions.

questions.question: A Product Owner proposes a Sprint Goal that focuses on 'completing as many Product Backlog items as possible.' What's problematic about this Sprint Goal?
options: It doesn't specify exact deliverables
It lacks focus and doesn't provide clear direction or value
It's too ambitious for the Development Team
It doesn't include specific acceptance criteria
questions.explanation: A good Sprint Goal should provide focus and clear direction toward a specific objective. 'Completing as many items as possible' lacks focus and doesn't help the team understand what value they're trying to deliver.

questions.question: A Product Owner wants to ensure the Development Team builds features exactly as specified. During the Sprint, the team proposes implementation changes that would deliver the same value more efficiently. How should the Product Owner respond?
options: Insist on the original specifications to maintain control
Collaborate with the team to understand the proposed changes and their impact on value
Allow any changes as long as the Development Team agrees
Escalate to the Scrum Master for a decision
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should collaborate with the team to understand proposed changes and their impact on value delivery. The team's technical insights combined with the Product Owner's value perspective often leads to better solutions.

questions.question: A Product Owner wants to improve Sprint Planning effectiveness. Which elements should they focus on during Sprint Planning? (Choose all that apply)
options: Clearly communicating the value and purpose of the Sprint (Why)
Collaborating on selecting achievable Product Backlog items (What)
Supporting the team's planning for delivery approach (How)
Assigning specific tasks to individual developers
questions.explanation: Sprint Planning addresses Why (Sprint Goal value), What (Product Backlog selection), and How (delivery planning). Task assignment is handled by the self-managing Development Team during execution.

questions.question: A Product Owner notices the Development Team frequently modifies the Sprint Backlog during the Sprint. They're concerned about scope creep. What should the Product Owner understand?
options: The Sprint Backlog should be frozen after Sprint Planning
Only the Product Owner should approve Sprint Backlog changes
The Development Team owns the Sprint Backlog and can modify it to achieve the Sprint Goal
Sprint Backlog changes indicate poor planning and should be prevented
questions.explanation: The Development Team owns and manages the Sprint Backlog, modifying it as they learn more about the work needed to achieve the Sprint Goal. This is normal and healthy adaptation, not scope creep.

questions.question: A Product Owner struggles to create meaningful Sprint Goals. Stakeholders complain that Sprint Goals are too vague to understand progress. What should the Product Owner focus on?
options: Creating detailed task lists instead of Sprint Goals
Writing Sprint Goals that articulate clear value and outcomes stakeholders can understand
Eliminating Sprint Goals since they're confusing stakeholders
Having the Development Team write Sprint Goals
questions.explanation: Sprint Goals should articulate clear value and outcomes that stakeholders can understand. They should answer 'why this Sprint matters' in terms that connect to business value and user outcomes.

questions.question: A Development Team tells the Product Owner they have more capacity than expected during the Sprint. The Product Owner wants to add a high-priority feature from the Product Backlog. What should guide this decision?
options: Always add the highest priority item from the Product Backlog
Only add work that supports or enhances the current Sprint Goal
Use the extra capacity for technical debt and refactoring
Save the capacity for unexpected issues that might arise
questions.explanation: Additional work should support or enhance the current Sprint Goal to maintain focus and coherence. Adding unrelated high-priority work, even if valuable, can fragment the Sprint's purpose and reduce the overall value delivered.

questions.question: A Product Owner learns that the Development Team is blocked by an external dependency that could take weeks to resolve. The impediment affects the Sprint Goal. What should the Product Owner do?
options: Wait for the Development Team to resolve the impediment
Use their stakeholder relationships to help resolve the impediment quickly
Cancel the Sprint since the Sprint Goal can't be achieved
Change the Sprint Goal to work around the impediment
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should leverage their stakeholder relationships and influence to help resolve impediments that threaten the Sprint Goal. They're often in the best position to escalate and coordinate with external parties.

questions.question: Midway through the Sprint, the Development Team realizes the Sprint Goal is unachievable due to underestimated complexity. They can deliver valuable functionality, just not what the Sprint Goal specified. What should the Product Owner do?
options: Insist the team work overtime to achieve the original Sprint Goal
Collaborate with the team to potentially adjust scope while preserving the Sprint Goal intent
Cancel the Sprint immediately since the Sprint Goal can't be met
Accept whatever the team can deliver and set a new Sprint Goal
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should collaborate with the team to find ways to preserve the Sprint Goal's intent while adjusting scope. The Sprint Goal should drive value-focused trade-offs rather than just accepting whatever gets done.

questions.question: A Product Owner is frustrated because the Development Team's Definition of Done seems to slow down delivery. They suggest lowering quality standards to deliver features faster. What should guide their thinking?
options: Definition of Done standards can be lowered to improve velocity
Quality standards ensure sustainable development and long-term value delivery
The Product Owner has authority to change the Definition of Done
Quality should be negotiated item by item based on priority
questions.explanation: The Definition of Done ensures sustainable development and long-term value delivery. Lowering quality standards creates technical debt that ultimately slows delivery and reduces value. Quality is an investment, not a cost.

questions.question: During the Sprint, stakeholders request changes to requirements based on new market information. The Development Team can accommodate the changes but it would impact other Sprint Backlog items. How should the Product Owner approach this?
options: Accept all changes since stakeholders know the market best
Reject all changes to protect the Sprint's stability
Evaluate changes against the Sprint Goal and make value-based trade-offs with the team
Postpone all changes until the next Sprint
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should evaluate changes against the Sprint Goal and work with the team to make value-based trade-offs. Some changes might enhance the Sprint Goal while others might detract from it.

questions.question: A Product Owner creates a detailed Sprint Goal, but the Development Team says the Sprint Backlog items don't align well with achieving that goal. What should the Product Owner do?
options: Keep the Sprint Goal and change the Sprint Backlog items
Keep the Sprint Backlog items and modify the Sprint Goal
Work with the team to align either the goal or the backlog items to create coherence
Start Sprint execution with the misalignment and resolve it during the Sprint
questions.explanation: The Sprint Goal and Sprint Backlog should be coherent and mutually supportive. The Product Owner should work with the team to align them, either by adjusting the goal to match valuable items or changing items to better achieve the goal.

questions.question: A Development Team discovers significant technical debt that affects their ability to implement current Sprint Backlog items effectively. How should the Product Owner respond?
options: Ignore technical debt and focus on delivering business features
Stop all feature work until technical debt is resolved
Work with the team to balance technical debt resolution with Sprint Goal achievement
Assign technical debt work to separate team members
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should work with the team to balance addressing technical debt with achieving the Sprint Goal. Technical debt that affects current work should be addressed, while other debt can be prioritized for future Sprints.

questions.question: A Product Owner proposes an ambitious Sprint Goal, but the Development Team says it's not achievable given their capacity and the complexity involved. What should happen?
options: The Product Owner should insist on the ambitious goal to push the team
The Development Team should commit regardless and work extra hours
They should collaborate to create a valuable but achievable Sprint Goal
They should skip Sprint Planning and work on individual items
questions.explanation: Sprint Planning should result in a Sprint Goal that the Development Team believes they can achieve while delivering significant value. Collaboration is needed to find the intersection of valuable and achievable.

questions.question: Two-thirds through the Sprint, the Development Team realizes they can't complete all Sprint Backlog items. However, they can still achieve the Sprint Goal with less scope. What should the Product Owner do?
options: Extend the Sprint to complete all committed items
Focus on Sprint Goal achievement and collaborate on scope trade-offs
Cancel the Sprint since not all items will be completed
Accept whatever gets done without considering the Sprint Goal
questions.explanation: The Sprint Goal is the primary commitment. The Product Owner should focus on achieving the Sprint Goal and collaborate with the team on scope trade-offs that preserve the most value within the constraint.

questions.question: Halfway through the Sprint, a critical customer escalation requires immediate attention. The Product Owner wants to add this work to the current Sprint. What should be the primary consideration?
options: Customer escalations always take priority and should be added immediately
No changes can be made to the Sprint once it has started
Whether the urgent work can be accommodated while preserving the Sprint Goal
The Development Team's preference about taking on additional work
questions.explanation: The primary consideration should be whether the urgent work can be accommodated while preserving the Sprint Goal. If the Sprint Goal would be jeopardized, the Product Owner should consider whether to cancel the Sprint or handle the escalation differently.

questions.question: A Product Owner wants to ensure Sprint Goals drive value delivery effectively. Which characteristics should their Sprint Goals have? (Choose all that apply)
options: Created collaboratively during Sprint Planning with the Development Team
Provide flexibility in implementation while maintaining clear objective
Remain stable throughout the Sprint to provide focus
Include specific implementation details to guide development
questions.explanation: Effective Sprint Goals are created collaboratively, provide flexibility while maintaining clear objectives, and remain stable for focus. They should not include implementation details, which are determined by the Development Team.

questions.question: The Development Team completes all Sprint Backlog items, but the Product Owner realizes the Sprint Goal hasn't been achieved. What should the Product Owner do?
options: Accept the completed items and end the Sprint successfully
Work with the team to identify what additional work would achieve the Sprint Goal
Change the Sprint Goal to match what was actually delivered
Cancel the Sprint since the goal wasn't achieved
questions.explanation: The Sprint Goal takes precedence over individual item completion. The Product Owner should work with the team to identify additional work that would achieve the Sprint Goal, since there's still time in the Sprint.

questions.question: A Product Owner learns that a competitor has released a feature similar to what their team is building. Stakeholders want to immediately pivot to a different feature. What should the Product Owner consider?
options: Immediately change direction to differentiate from the competitor
Evaluate whether the current Sprint Goal is still valuable or has become obsolete
Continue with the current Sprint regardless of competitive changes
Split the team to work on both the current and new features
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should evaluate whether the competitive change makes the current Sprint Goal obsolete or less valuable. If the goal is still valuable, continue; if not, consider canceling the Sprint to replan.

questions.question: A Product Owner has been unavailable for several days during the Sprint due to urgent business travel. The Development Team is blocked on decisions about acceptance criteria and feature behavior. What's the core issue?
options: The Development Team should be more self-sufficient in making product decisions
The Product Owner must ensure availability to support the team during Sprint execution
The Scrum Master should make product decisions when the Product Owner is unavailable
Product decisions should all be made upfront to avoid this situation
questions.explanation: The Product Owner has an accountability to be available to support the team during Sprint execution. Extended unavailability prevents value delivery and violates the collaborative foundation of Scrum.

questions.question: During the Sprint, a Product Owner realizes that two Sprint Backlog items, while technically correct, won't deliver the expected business value. What should they do?
options: Let the team complete the items since they were committed to in Sprint Planning
Work with the team to reprioritize within the Sprint toward the Sprint Goal
Remove the items and extend the Sprint to add better items
Document the learning for future Sprint Planning improvement
questions.explanation: The Product Owner should work with the team to reprioritize within the Sprint toward achieving the Sprint Goal with maximum value. Sprint commitments are to the goal, not to individual items.
